repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

Currently, progress-api takes in additional info from the user (title, status, percent) but doesn't display them anywhere in the.

### Solution

Format tui messages as `{title}: {msg}...{percent}%`. This also gets sent to UI. This was originally part of #34846 but was deferred to simplify the pr.

### Advantage
With specific formatting sent to UI we can remove the progress attribute from `msg_show` event. Since we are still not sure about it, it's best if we don't rush it in. Instead, it can be added if needed in the future. Also, with default formatting set UI by default has a better behavior (for adding support to `vim._extui` we just need to implement the replace msg on same id instruction). And TUI also represents progress-messages more progress like. And if any UI/plugin want's to do anything fancier Progress event provides all the tools they need.

comment_data.body: Unnecessary for such a short-lived feature on master.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,6 +39,11 @@ TREESITTER
 
 • todo
 
+UI
+
+• `progress` attribute removed form |ui-messages| msg_show event

comment_data.body: True. But shouldn't we still do it to follow procedure :] ? Also, this is just marked breaking for `dev`. Won't get published with a changelog I believe.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,6 +39,11 @@ TREESITTER
 
 • todo
 
+UI
+
+• `progress` attribute removed form |ui-messages| msg_show event

comment_data.body: Is this still shown if `ext_messages` is enabled?
They can still get autocmd events right? They can just filter out messages with "progress" kind. And show whatever they want to, using data from `Progress` autocmd event
I am asking the opposite: I don't see where this is gated. It sounds like it is though.

> Is this still shown if `ext_messages` is enabled?

It is. Consider this default. Normally default behavior of ext_ui is to mimic TUI, right? This basically gives ext_ui a good starting point. If they want, they can customize further at their discretion. That was my thought at least.

> I am asking the opposite: I don't see where this is gated. It sounds like it is, though.

If you remember, I had it gated on the original pr (this [patch](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34846/commits/c87468c3c160dfb2d3db84869e4565d40b44cb67)) to be exact. In this pr this is not gated. The format is always used for progress messages. After some thought, I think providing a default format is better. ext-ui by default will have decent behavior.

comment_regular_data.body:
> Question then becomes what happens with the regular message in case a Progress handler (plugin) displays the event. Will probably end up needing some sort of message option to disable extui progress messages for the plugin use case if we show a notification by default.

Tbh I was thinking in terms of ext-ui. They can filter messages out messages based on kind.

Also, I haven't yet looked at it but if we make `vim._extui` on by default. Adding a filter there won't be hard, right?

> > And if any UI/plugin want's to do anything fancier Progress event provides all the tools they need.
> 
> Question then becomes what happens with the regular message in case a Progress handler (plugin) displays the event.

All `Progress` handlers have the message `id`, and should call `nvim_echo` with that `id`. Then the UI must update that message in-place. I don't see a problem, what am I missing?

> needing some sort of message option to disable extui progress messages for the plugin use case if we show a notification by default.

I would expect the extui "notification" presentation to update the message in-place if a `msg_show` UI event is received with a matching `id`.

> Format tui messages as `{title}: {msg}...{percent}%`. This also gets sent to UI. This was originally part of #34846 but was deferred to simplify the pr.

May I ask (as I don't really understand the change here) if `nvim_echo()` caller still can adjust the shown message? `vim.pack` shows these parts with different highlighting and order, for example.

> if `nvim_echo()` caller still can adjust the shown message? `vim.pack` shows these parts with different highlighting and order

If you want to control formatting, don't set `type=progress`, that defeats the purpose. Having a consistent presentation is one of the goals of `type=progress`. Though the current form can be improved.

> > Question then becomes what happens with the regular message in case a Progress handler (plugin) displays the event.

> All Progress handlers have the message id, and should call nvim_echo with that id. Then the UI must update that message in-place. I don't see a problem, what am I missing?

I was talking about when the Progress event is handled (by a user plugin) to display the message somewhere (statusline, floating window?), the msg_show UI event will still come through to display display it a second time. Unrelated to IDs or replacing messages (I can update extui to do so when this is stabilized).

> > if `nvim_echo()` caller still can adjust the shown message? `vim.pack` shows these parts with different highlighting and order
> 
> If you want to control formatting, don't set `type=progress`, that defeats the purpose. Having a consistent presentation is one of the goals of `type=progress`. Though the current form can be improved.

Then may I suggest following [the format](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bc6737250d61703d07d7a95ba83ebf841f5454b9/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua#L395-L397) of what is currently done in `vim.pack`? Having different highlighting for parts and aligning percent to the right improves visuals a lot.

And one of the initial goals (originated in `vim.ui.progress`) was to allow dedicated "progress message" plugins to decide how they want to show the progress.

> I was talking about when the Progress event is handled (by a user plugin) to display the message somewhere (statusline, floating window?), the msg_show UI event will still come through to display it a second time. Unrelated to IDs or replacing messages (I can update extui to do so when this is stabilized).

This is something I've been thinking about. But don't have an elegant solution to the possible double representation yet (`'progressfmt'` as an option, anyone)? Usually things to `vim.ui` that can be overridden, but in this case, in integrated with `nvim_echo` So that doesn't seem feasible here. 

If you have any ideas or thoughts on this, please share.

> Then may I suggest following [the format](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bc6737250d61703d07d7a95ba83ebf841f5454b9/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua#L395-L397) of what is currently done in vim.pack? Having different highlighting for parts and aligning percent to the right improves visuals a lot.

> And one of the initial goals (originated in vim.ui.progress) was to allow dedicated "progress message" plugins to decide how they want to show the progress.

The formatting definitely can be improved from what we have here. Particularly, I think we can add different highlighting to indicate different statuses. I was actually planning to discuss a bit further on what the best format for this would be. The format can be updated in a followup pr. So a discussion is still helpful.

btw, on the formatting on `vim.pack`, did you mean the use of custom fmt function?

> btw, on the formatting on `vim.pack`, did you mean the use of custom fmt function?

Not quite, more so that it can be closer to the way it [currently displays progress](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35052#issuecomment-3137390768). But if now it emits new message on every progress update, with `type='progress'` it will be a single updated message without cluttering message history.

I am, of course, open to other formatting and highlighting. Especially if a more general "progress report" requires it. Just that the current one seems to be a good combination of minimal and useful.

> Particularly, I think we can add different highlighting to indicate different statuses.

I like the idea of highlighting statuses differently. It can be:
- `{ percent, 'WarningMsg' }` for `running`. I.e. show percent directly instead of "running".
- `{ 'done', 'MoreMsg' }` for `success`.
- `{ 'failed', 'ErrorMsg' }` for `failed`.
- `{ 'cancel', 'MsgArea' }` for `cancel`.

>And if any UI/plugin want's to do anything fancier Progress event provides all the tools they need.

How does a UI respond to autocmd events?

> How does a UI respond to autocmd events?

That's a [solvable problem](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35481#issuecomment-3222403109). #34399

> Not quite, more so that it can be closer to the way it currently displays progress

Displaying the percent before the msg looks like a better format. It keeps it in consistent place. We can do `{title}: {percent}% {msg}` And highlightings look decent. I'll experiment a bit. Then hopefully create a pr.

> with type='progress' it will be a single updated message without cluttering message history.

About not cluttering history. We are still doing that :]. Msg replace on history was droped from #34846

@justinmk @luukvbaal I still think replacing msg in history in place has value. Maybe we can just store the formated text in exsisting fields without introducing the msgData fields? Is that acceptable? Particularly single message for each progress message really feel like clutters the history to me. Maybe we just update the hisotry entry without droping it to bottom?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(progress): simplify progress ui-event and introduce default formating
